contentrichtext.text: [[File:Granite island as seen from the tram station.jpg|thumb|Granite Island as seen from the tram station]] [[File:Ticket prices and Time Table.jpg|thumb|Ticket prices and Time Table (Granite Island)]] [[File:Tram Station.jpg|thumb|Tram Station situated on the Granite Island]] [[File:20040610 Victor Harbor Tramway.jpg|thumb|right|Tramcar on the causeway]] [[File:VictorHarborFromGranite Island.jpg|thumb|right|The causeway, seen from Granite Island]] [[File:Granite Island.jpg|thumb|right|Tram track on Granite Island]] [[File:Tramway Horse Victor Harbor BF 003.JPG|thumb|right|Tramcar at the mainland terminus]] The '''Victor Harbor Horse Drawn Tram''' is located in the city of [[Victor Harbor, South Australia|Victor Harbor]], [[South Australia]], [[Australia]]. The [[tram]]way links the visitor information centre in downtown Victor Harbor with the nearby [[Granite Island (Australia)|Granite Island]], running for half of its route over a 630 metre wooden [[viaduct]] or [[pier]], locally described as a causeway. It is one of the very few [[Horsecar|horse-drawn tram]] routes remaining in public transit service anywhere in the world, and provides service every day throughout the year. There are four tramcars, each hauled by one of 8 [[Clydesdale (breed)|Clydesdale]] [[horse]]s. The line is built to {{railgauge|1600}} gauge, as are the railways of South Australia. ==History== The [[South Australian Railways]] (SAR) reached Victor Harbor in 1864, when a railway connected pier was constructed. In 1867 this pier was extended to reach Granite Island, the resulting link becaming known as "The Causeway". The railway line continued onto and around the northern edge of the island to where a jetty was constructed. Although railway goods vehicles were routinely horse hauled on this line, no passenger service was offered until 1894, when the SAR decided to utilise an unused horse-drawn tram to offer a passenger service.<ref name=arh72>{{cite journal | last1 = Harris | first1 = G.G. | year = 1972 | month = May | title = The Victor Harbour Horse Tram | journal = [[Australian Railway History|Australian Railway Historical Society Bulletin]] | pages = 97–101}}</ref><ref name=ehhdt>{{cite web | title = Early History of the Horse Drawn Tram | url = http://www.horsedrawntram.com.au/early_history.html | publisher = City of Victor Harbor | accessdate = 2011-01-17}}</ref> From 1900, the horse tramway was operated by private contractors, George and Frank Honeyman, on behalf of the SAR. By the 1950s, the causeway was in need of repair, but a dispute between the operators and the local council meant that in 1954 the causeway was reconstructed without rail tracks. The service continued to operate on Granite Island itself until 1956, when the cars were disposed of. Between 1956 and 1986, a [[Trackless train|rubber tyred train]] provided service across the causeway.<ref name=ehhdt/> The 150th jubilee of [[South Australia]] was due to be celebrated in 1986, and a fund was established for special projects to mark the jubilee. Reinstatement of the horse tram was nominated as such a project, and the bid was successful. Replica tram cars were built, tracks were relaid and service recommenced on 14 June 1986.<ref name=ehhdt/><ref name=arh86>{{cite journal | last1 = Bird | first1 = Kim | year = 1986 | month = September |title = Victor Harbour Horse Tram Return | journal = [[Australian Railway History|Australian Railway Historical Society Bulletin]] | pages = 207–211}}</ref> ==See also== *[[Douglas Horse Tram]], another horse drawn tramway on the [[Isle of Man]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Victor Harbor Horse Drawn Tram}} *[http://www.horsedrawntram.com.au/ Victor Harbor Horse Drawn Tram web site] *[http://www.victor.sa.gov.au/site/page.cfm?u=321 City of Victor Harbor's pages on the tram] {{TramsAustralia}} {{coord|-35.5606|138.6277|type:landmark_region:AU|display=title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} [[Category:Fleurieu Peninsula]] [[Category:Horsecar lines]] [[Category:Pier railways]] [[Category:Transport in South Australia]] [[Category:Tram transport in Australia]] [[Category:5ft 3in gauge railways]] [[Category:Visitor attractions in South Australia]]
